column3: Question
column9: Explanation

column3: Replacement bridge total length is:
column9: Proposed replacement bridge (Br. No. 27-0124) is a three-span precast/prestressed slab structure with total length 162 ft.

column3: Planned delivery method for the replacement bridge is:
column9: The replacement bridge will be constructed using the Accelerated Bridge Construction (ABC) technique.

column3: Existing 1929 bridge configuration is:
column9: Existing bridge (Br. No. 27-0023) built in 1929 is a three-span structure with steel truss middle span and RC end-spans.

column3: Project is located on:
column9: Contract documents identify Route 1 in Marin County at Point Reyes Station.

column3: Begin construction station (A-line) is shown as:
column9: Plans title sheet shows BEGIN CONSTRUCTION at Sta "A" 15+45.

column3: End construction station (A-line) is shown as:
column9: Plans title sheet shows END CONSTRUCTION at Sta "A" 21+25.

column3: Total working days for the contract is:
column9: Bid Summary lists total number of working days as 300.

column3: Engineer's Estimate is closest to:
column9: Bid Summary shows Engineer's Estimate about $19.12M.

column3: Low bid (total) is closest to:
column9: Low bid shown as $18,303,333.

column3: Low bidder listed in the bid summary is:
column9: Bid Summary lists MYERS-DISNEY JV as low bidder.

column3: Addendum 1 made which meeting mandatory?
column9: Addendum 1 adds a Mandatory Prebid Meeting and Job Site Visit.

column3: Mandatory prebid meeting date was:
column9: Addendum 1 states January 15, 2026.

column3: Mandatory prebid meeting time was:
column9: Addendum 1 states 10:00 a.m.

column3: Addendum 2 added a special notice about:
column9: Addendum 2 adds a special notice pointing to Buy America/Build America requirements.

column3: South-side bedrock depth is about:
column9: South profile indicates bedrock at about 64 ft (elev ~ -44 ft).

column3: North-side bedrock depth is about:
column9: North profile indicates bedrock at about 97 ft (elev ~ -77 ft).

column3: Bedrock unit described at site is:
column9: Foundation report describes Franciscan Complex mélange (Block-in-Matrix rock).

column3: To convert 1929 local datum elevations to NAVD 88, you should:
column9: Foundation report notes local datum can be converted to NAVD 88 by adding ~12.1 ft.

column3: Which boring was drilled to 140 ft to confirm bedrock conditions?
column9: RW-24-001 (03/28/2024) was drilled to 140 ft adjacent to RW-18-012 to confirm subsurface/bedrock conditions.

column3: Why was RW-24-001 drilled after RW-18-012?
column5: RW-18-012 was terminated short due to community complaints
column9: RW-18-012 stopped ~95 ft due to local complaints; RW-24-001 drilled to planned deeper depth.

column3: Which two borings were drilled south of Abutment 1?
column9: Foundation report states RW-16-002 and RW-18-011 were south of Abutment 1.

column3: Which borings were drilled north of Abutment 4?
column9: North side borings include RW-16-001, RW-18-012, and RW-24-001.

column3: SPT blow counts were recorded at intervals of:
column9: Foundation report notes SPT blow counts recorded either at 5-foot or 10-foot intervals.

column3: Which boring recorded groundwater elevation at about 1.0 ft?
column9: Table 1 shows RW-18-011 groundwater elevation ~1.0 ft.

column3: Which boring recorded groundwater elevation at about 2.0 ft?
column9: Table 1 shows RW-18-012 groundwater elevation ~2.0 ft.

column3: Which boring recorded groundwater elevation at about 4.8 ft?
column9: Table 1 shows RW-16-001 groundwater elevation ~4.8 ft.

column3: RW-16-001 SPT hammer efficiency was approximately:
column9: Table 1 shows RW-16-001 hammer efficiency 92%.

column3: RW-16-002 used a manual hammer with efficiency about:
column9: Table 1 shows RW-16-002 manual hammer efficiency 54%.

column3: RW-18-011 auto hammer efficiency was approximately:
column9: Table 1 shows RW-18-011 auto hammer efficiency 75%.

column3: RW-18-012 hammer efficiency changed at about:
column9: Table 1 notes 75% up to 70 ft and 52% below 70 ft.

column3: South profile top layer (~13 ft) is described as:
column9: South profile includes about 13 ft of loose silty sand at the top.

column3: South profile includes a ~15-ft layer described as:
column9: South profile includes ~15-ft thick soft to medium stiff clay.

column3: In the south profile, the 11-ft thick layer is described as:
column9: South profile includes an ~11-ft thick very dense clayey gravel layer.

column3: In the south profile, the second clay layer is approximately:
column5: 25 ft thick, very stiff to hard
column9: South profile includes another ~25-ft thick very stiff to hard clay layer below the gravel.

column3: North profile before bedrock includes about 82 ft of:
column9: North profile consists of ~82 ft of sandy and gravelly soils before the clay layer.

column3: North profile clay layer above bedrock is about:
column9: North profile includes a ~15-ft thick hard gravelly lean clay layer.

column3: North profile upper portion (to ~34 ft) is described as:
column9: North profile upper sandy/gravelly soils up to ~34 ft are very loose to medium dense.

column3: South-side bedrock is described as:
column9: Foundation report describes bedrock as fine to medium grained slightly weathered sedimentary rock (graywacke).

column3: The regional fault zone noted near the project is:
column9: Foundation report notes Tomales Bay partially fills the San Andreas fault zone.

column3: Shallow groundwater (1–5 ft) most directly affects:
column9: Groundwater near the surface increases need for excavation/drilling stability measures and potential dewatering.

column3: Compared to the south side, the north side likely has:
column5: Deeper bedrock and longer drilling cycles
column9: North bedrock ~97 ft vs south ~64 ft implies longer drilling/excavation cycles north.

column3: A boring with cave-in conditions suggests you should plan for:
column5: Casing or other hole stability measures
column9: Cave-in indicates unstable conditions and need for stability measures.

column3: A documented community complaint during drilling means you should:
column5: Plan for public sensitivity and potential operational constraints
column9: Complaints can trigger constraints; plan communications and compliant operations.

column3: If elevations are taken from 1929 as-builts, you should:
column5: Confirm datum and apply +12.1 ft conversion (approx.)
column9: Foundation report indicates local datum conversion to NAVD88 by adding ~12.1 ft.

column3: BiMRock conditions most likely cause:
column9: Block-in-matrix rock includes hard blocks in a weaker matrix—high variability.

column3: If a crew begins work outside Sta 'A' 15+45 to 21+25, the primary risk is:
column5: Working outside contract limits/traffic control planning
column9: Begin/end stations define project limits and staging/traffic planning boundaries.

column3: Replacement bridge superstructure type is described as:
column9: Foundation report describes a three-span precast/prestressed concrete slab structure.

column3: A mandatory prebid meeting requirement primarily signals:
column9: Addendum 1 established the meeting as mandatory for bidders.

column3: Buy America/Build America requirements most directly affect:
column9: Addendum 2 adds requirements for manufactured products.

column3: Why should field staff know which borings are near which abutment?
column5: To anticipate local ground behavior during construction
column9: Boring locations inform localized soil/rock variability and methods planning.

column3: Number of bidders shown in the bid summary is:
column9: Bid Summary shows Number of Bidders: 5.

column3: Low bid compared to Engineer's Estimate was roughly:
column9: Bid Summary shows an underrun of about -19.18%.

column3: If a horizontal construction joint is not shown for curb/barrier, the safest field action is:
column4: Place it anyway to speed up
column9: Bidder inquiry response points back to standard spec language: joints only where described unless authorized.

column3: RW-16-001 total boring depth was approximately:
column9: Table 1 lists RW-16-001 total depth about 80 ft.

column3: RW-16-001 was completed in which year?
column9: Table 1 shows completion date 07/19/2016.

column3: RW-16-001 is on the north side of the bridge in the Foundation Report summary.
column9: Foundation report summarizes RW-16-001 as drilled on the north side of the bridge.

column3: RW-16-002 total boring depth was approximately:
column9: Table 1 lists RW-16-002 total depth about 80 ft.

column3: RW-16-002 was completed in which year?
column9: Table 1 shows completion date 08/17/2016.

column3: RW-16-002 is on the south side of the bridge in the Foundation Report summary.
column9: Foundation report summarizes RW-16-002 as drilled on the south side of the bridge.

column3: RW-18-011 total boring depth was approximately:
column9: Table 1 lists RW-18-011 total depth about 107.5 ft.

column3: RW-18-011 was completed in which year?
column9: Table 1 shows completion date 11/16/2018.

column3: RW-18-011 is on the south side of the bridge in the Foundation Report summary.
column9: Foundation report summarizes RW-18-011 as drilled on the south side of the bridge.

column3: RW-18-012 total boring depth was approximately:
column9: Table 1 lists RW-18-012 total depth about 95.2 ft.

column3: RW-18-012 was completed in which year?
column9: Table 1 shows completion date 11/26/2018.

column3: RW-18-012 is on the north side of the bridge in the Foundation Report summary.
column9: Foundation report summarizes RW-18-012 as drilled on the north side of the bridge.

column3: RW-24-001 total boring depth was approximately:
column9: Table 1 lists RW-24-001 total depth about 140 ft.

column3: RW-24-001 was completed in which year?
column9: Table 1 shows completion date 03/28/2024.

column3: RW-24-001 is on the north side of the bridge in the Foundation Report summary.
column9: Foundation report summarizes RW-24-001 as drilled on the north side of the bridge.

column3: Why did the Foundation Report develop separate idealized profiles north vs south?
column5: Soil/rock conditions differ by side and piers are close to abutments
column9: Piers and abutments are close (~30 ft), and subsurface conditions differ north vs south, so separate profiles were used.

column3: Abutment 1 and Pier 2 are roughly how far apart (per Foundation Report narrative)?
column9: Foundation Report notes Abutment 1 and Pier 2 are only about 30 ft apart.

column3: Pier 3 and Abutment 4 are roughly how far apart (per Foundation Report narrative)?
column9: Foundation Report notes Pier 3 and Abutment 4 are only about 30 ft apart.

column3: Rock coring was performed in which borings?
column9: Foundation Report states rock coring was performed in RW-18-011 and RW-24-001.

column3: Which boring had cave-in conditions at about 35 ft?
column9: Foundation Report notes RW-18-012 had cave-in conditions at about 35 ft.

column3: Which boring experienced continuous drilling fluid loss during drilling?
column9: Foundation Report notes RW-16-001 had continuous drilling fluid loss.

column3: Which side has deeper bedrock based on the idealized profiles?
column9: North bedrock ~97 ft vs south ~64 ft.

column3: Buy America/Build America notice most affects what early action?
column5: Confirm manufactured product compliance and documentation before ordering
column9: Addendum 2 adds manufactured products compliance requirements.

column3: A prior drilling complaint most directly threatens:
column9: Foundation report documents complaints affecting drilling progression; anticipate community constraints.

column3: Very low RQD (0–12%) most directly implies:
column5: Highly fractured rock and variable drilling behavior
column9: Low RQD indicates poor rock quality—fractured and variable.

column3: Why is it useful that Pier 2 is only ~30 ft from Abutment 1?
column5: Boring info near the abutment is relevant for adjacent pier conditions
column9: Close spacing means the local profile influences both units.

column3: With 300 working days, the best superintendent-level habit is:
column5: Control weekly production and constraints tightly
column9: Tight time requires consistent production tracking and constraint removal.

column9: Foundation report notes 1929 drawings appear to use local datum; conversion to NAVD 88 is ~+12.1 ft.

column5: Plan for wet conditions and manage water in excavations

column3: Before UHPC mock-up starts you must submit the UHPC materials order showing:
column9: Specs require copy of UHPC materials order with manufacturer type and quantity sufficient for mock-up testing production and waste.

column3: UHPC work plan must cover storage mixing delivery placement curing and:
column9: Specs require a UHPC work plan for storage mixing delivery placement curing and finishing.

column3: UHPC work plan must include methods to prevent what during placement and curing?
column9: Specs require methods for prevention of vibration and loading of UHPC during placement and curing.

column3: UHPC work plan must include methods to prevent what during cure between adjacent girders?
column9: Specs require methods to prevent relative displacement along the joint between adjacent girders during UHPC cure.

column3: Who authorizes the UHPC work plan for production work?
column9: Engineer authorizes UHPC work plan after successful completion of mock-up.

column3: After authorization what must be kept at the jobsite?
column9: Specs require maintaining a copy of the authorized UHPC work plan at the jobsite.

column3: Batching records must include mixer identification or serial number and:
column9: Specs list batching record requirements including date and time and mixer identification.

column3: Batching records must include the time of:
column9: Specs require time of water addition in batching records.

column3: Batching records must include amount of water and ice added:
column9: Specs require amount of water and ice added after initial mixing.

column3: Batching records must include total mixing time and:
column9: Specs require total mixing time and time of discharge.

column3: Batching records must include ambient temperature and:
column9: Specs require ambient temperature and batch temperature at initial discharge.

column3: Batching records must include result of which fresh property test?
column9: Specs require result of flow test in batching records.

column3: Strength-maturity validation report readings must be taken at maximum intervals of:
column9: Specs require readings at a maximum of 15-minute intervals.

column3: Which method is NOT allowed to determine maturity index?
column4: Instrument that displays maturity index directly
column5: Temperature logger used to calculate maturity index
column9: Specs prohibit using temperature loggers to calculate maturity index.

column3: Before placing UHPC you must prequalify:
column5: Materials mix proportions mixing equipment and procedures
column9: Specs require prequalification of UHPC materials mix proportions mixing equipment and procedures.

column3: UHPC mock-up must demonstrate UHPC flows for the distance required by:
column9: Specs require mock-up demonstrate flow distance required by proposed construction procedure.

column3: UHPC mock-up must demonstrate UHPC completely fills forms and spaces and:
column9: Specs require mock-up demonstrate complete filling and no leakage during placement.

column3: UHPC mock-up must demonstrate reinforcement and embedments are:
column9: Specs require full encapsulation of reinforcement and embedment.

column3: UHPC mock-up must demonstrate steel fibers are:
column9: Specs require uniform fiber distribution with no segregation.

column3: Minimum required PC/UHPC mock-ups is:
column9: Specs require constructing at least 2 PC/UHPC mock-ups.

column3: UHPC for mock-ups must use the same personnel materials equipment mix design and methods as:
column9: Specs require mock-up replicate production conditions including personnel and methods.

column3: Before pre-wetting forms or leak tests you must seal keyways joints forms and casings with:
column5: Joint sealant per authorized work plan
column9: Specs require sealing with joint sealant before pre-wetting or leak tests.

column3: Pre-wet UHPC receiving surface for a minimum of:
column9: Specs require minimum 2 hours pre-wetting to reach saturated surface-dry condition.

column3: UHPC work plan must include securing what between modules for pouring UHPC?
column9: Specs require a watertight bottom temporary form between modules.

column3: UHPC work plan must include forming with vents and seals to prevent:
column9: Specs require forming including vents and seals for leak prevention.

column3: Top forms must be non-absorbent and secured to resist:
column9: Specs require top forms resist hydrostatic pressure.

column3: UHPC work plan must include providing and maintaining:
column9: Specs require maintaining hydrostatic head during placement.

column3: UHPC work plan requires overfilling UHPC spaces by approximately:
column9: Specs require overfilling by about 3/8 inch.

column3: UHPC work plan must include method for intermixing separate pours if:
column9: Specs require methods to intermix separate pours if flow is interrupted.

column3: UHPC work plan must include maintaining external curing temperature until:
column5: 18-hour strength is achieved by cylinder breaks
column9: Specs require maintaining curing temperature until 18-hour strength is obtained as evidenced by cylinder breaks.

column3: For each mixing and placing of UHPC who must be present?
column9: Specs require UHPC manufacturer representative present for each mixing and placing.

column3: UHPC preconstruction meeting must be held after authorization of mock-up work plan and at least:
column9: Specs require mandatory UHPC preconstruction meeting at least 5 days before starting mock-up work.

column3: UHPC preconstruction meeting attendees must include Engineer and:
column5: UHPC manufacturer rep and field QC plus sampling and testing personnel
column9: Specs list required attendees including UHPC manufacturer rep and field QC/testing personnel.

column3: UHPC preconstruction meeting discussion should include QC sampling and testing including:
column9: Specs require discussion including end grinding of cylinders.

column3: For UHPC mock-up temperature sensors must be placed:
column5: At each end and about 5-foot centers
column9: Specs require sensors at each end and about 5-foot centers with exact locations directed by Engineer.

column3: During UHPC mock-up cylinders must validate strengths at 12 hr 14 hr 18 hr and:
column9: Specs require validation including 56-day strength.

column3: After UHPC mock-up attains 12 ksi you must cut each mock-up at:
column9: Specs require cutting at 3 locations to validate mixing encapsulation fiber distribution no cold joints and filling.

column3: After mock-up cuts allow Engineer how long for review?
column9: Specs require allowing 5 business days for review.

column3: If Engineer rejects a mock-up you must submit revised mock-up and UHPC work plans and allow review of:
column9: Specs require allowing 7 days for review of revised work plans.

column3: Department acceptance of UHPC includes sampling testing and inspections performed by:
column9: Specs define Department acceptance includes Department sampling testing and inspections.

column3: UHPC acceptance flow requirement is ASTM C1856 with range:
column9: Acceptance table lists flow 7-10 inches under ASTM C1856.

column3: UHPC acceptance requires compressive strength of 12 ksi at 18 hours and:
column9: Acceptance table includes 20 ksi at 56 days.

column3: A UHPC compressive test represents no more than:
column9: Specs state a compressive test represents no more than 25 cu yd and is average of 5 cylinders from one load.

column3: UHPC compressive test cylinders must be prepared using:
column9: Specs require automatic concrete cylinder end grinding.

column3: UHPC compressive strength testing must be performed at:
column5: AASHTO-accredited lab capable of end grinding
column9: Specs require AASHTO-accredited laboratory capable of end grinding.

column3: UHPC used for mock-up and production must be from same manufacturer and same:
column9: Specs require same manufacturer and same lot or batch number.

column3: UHPC manufacture date must be no more than how long before production placement?
column9: Specs require manufacture date no more than 18 months before UHPC is placed in production.

column3: PC surfaces in contact with UHPC must have exposed aggregate finish minimum amplitude of:
column9: Specs require minimum amplitude 1/8 inch with average 1/4 inch.

column3: PC surfaces in contact with UHPC must have exposed aggregate finish average amplitude of:
column9: Specs require average amplitude 1/4 inch.

column3: Before shipping precast members you must preassemble to verify geometry and field connections and:
column5: Assemble PC elements in the order shown
column9: Specs require assembling PC elements in the order shown during preassembly.

column3: Notify Engineer at least how many days before preassembly?
column9: Specs require notifying Engineer at least 5 days before preassembly and performing in Engineer presence.

column3: Preassembly must be performed in the presence of:
column9: Specs require preassembly in the presence of the Engineer.

column3: After preassembly you must:
column9: Specs require disassembling precast members before shipping to job site.

column3: Apply what to PC surfaces to be in contact with UHPC?
column9: Specs require applying form retarder to PC concrete surfaces to be in contact with UHPC under manufacturer instructions.

column3: Concrete for connecting joints between PC/PS concrete box girders must be:
column9: Specs require connecting joints constructed using UHPC.

column3: Plans state construction equipment loads are not allowed until UHPC joint strength reaches:
column9: Plans note construction equipment loads not allowed until UHPC joints reach 12 ksi.

column3: Plans state full traffic loads are not allowed until UHPC joint strength reaches:
column9: Plans note full traffic loads not allowed until UHPC joints reach 14 ksi.

column3: Plans state UHPC may be ground flush after UHPC reaches:
column9: Plans note grinding flush after UHPC has reached 14 ksi.

column3: Plans note UHPC joint reinforcement #5 must be:
column9: Plans require #5 UHPC joint reinforcement galvanized in entirety whether spliced or unspliced.

column3: Concrete for abutments and bent caps must be constructed using:
column9: Specs state abutments and bent caps must be constructed using RSC.

column3: Portions required to be constructed as mass concrete are:
column9: Specs table identifies bent caps and abutments as mass concrete under section 51-6.

column3: Submit an RSC work placement plan at least how many days before use?
column9: Specs require submitting RSC work placement plan at least 10 days before use.

column3: RSC work placement plan must include methods and procedures for storing handling transporting and:
column9: Specs require staging materials at the job site and include mixing QC and placing finishing curing.

column3: RSC work placement plan must include methods and procedures for QC sampling and testing and:
column9: Specs require plan include QC sampling and testing and placing finishing and curing.

column3: Submit a contingency plan for correcting problems during transportation production placement or:
column9: Specs require a contingency plan for correcting problems during transportation production placement or finishing of RSC.

column3: Submit an RSC work placement plan for mock-up construction at least:
column9: Specs require RSC mock-up work placement plan at least 10 days before constructing mock-up.

column3: After mock-up you must submit:
column9: Specs require submitting compressive strength test results from the mock-up.

column3: RSC QC manager must hold current ACI certifications:
column4: Concrete Field Testing Grade I only
column5: Concrete Laboratory Testing Grade II only
column6: Both Field Testing Grade I and Lab Testing Grade II
column9: Specs require QC manager holds ACI Concrete Field Testing Technician Grade I and Concrete Laboratory Testing Technician Grade II.

column3: QC manager must review and sign sampling inspection and test reports before:
column9: Specs require QC manager review and sign reports before submitting.

column3: QC manager must be present for establishing volumetric mixer control settings and:
column5: Mock-up construction and meetings with Engineer
column9: Specs list QC manager presence requirements including mock-up construction and meetings related to production placement or testing.

column3: QC manager must not be a member of production or paving crews and must not be an inspector or:
column9: Specs prohibit QC manager being production crew inspector or tester.

column3: During production and placement of RSC QC manager must have no duties except those:
column9: Specs state QC manager must have no duties during production and placement of RSC except those specified.

column3: Schedule and hold a preconstruction meeting at least how many business days before RSC work?
column9: Specs require preconstruction meeting at least 5 business days before RSC work.

column3: For the RSC preconstruction meeting who provides the meeting facility?
column9: Specs require contractor provide meeting facility.

column3: The RSC meeting must include the Engineer and your reps and any subcontractors involved in:
column9: Specs require meeting include subcontractors involved in RSC work.

column3: RSC preconstruction meeting discussion should include storing and staging materials QC sampling and testing mixing placing finishing curing and:
column9: Specs list agenda includes contingency plan.

column3: Construct a mock-up for each type of bridge element to be constructed with:
column9: Specs require mock-up for each type of bridge element to be constructed with RSC.

column3: For abutments and bent caps the RSC mock-up must be a rectangular block:
column9: Specs define abutment and bent cap mock-up block size 6 x 4.67 x 42 ft.

column3: RSC mock-up must be constructed using personnel materials tools equipment and methods to be used in:
column9: Specs require mock-up use same resources and methods as production RSC work.

column3: RSC mock-up forms must be similar to forms used for production element and include RSC reinforcement and:
column9: Specs require including reinforcement and concrete embedments shown.

column3: RSC mock-up must demonstrate you can construct a bridge element within anticipated time periods including delivery placement finishing curing and in:
column5: Similar atmospheric conditions expected during construction
column9: Specs require similar atmospheric conditions expected during construction.

column3: RSC mock-up must demonstrate thermal control plan temperature data daily daily progress report and max allowable temperature differential comply with:
column9: Specs require mock-up demonstrate mass concrete controls comply with section 51-6.01C.

column3: RSC in the mock-up must be placed in the presence of the:
column9: Specs require placing RSC in mock-up in the Engineers presence.

column3: RSC compressive strength testing must be performed and cylinders prepared under:
column9: Specs require cylinders prepared under California Test 540 Method 2 for RSC mock-up testing.

column3: RSC for mock-up must develop minimum compressive strength of 3000 psi at:
column9: Specs list minimum 3000 psi at 24 hours.

column3: RSC for mock-up must develop minimum compressive strength of 4000 psi at:
column9: Specs list minimum 4000 psi at age of break and 4000 psi at 28 days.

column3: RSC for mock-up must develop minimum compressive strength of 4000 psi at:
column9: Specs list minimum 4000 psi at 28 days.

column3: For RSC mock-up you must saw cut the mock-up:
column9: Specs require saw cutting the mock-up full-depth as directed.

column3: If Engineer rejects RSC mock-up you must:
column9: Specs require additional mock-ups until authorized and mock-up must be authorized before starting RSC work.

column3: Dispose of the RSC mock-up:
column9: Specs state dispose of the mock-up after it is authorized and directed.

column3: RSC used for constructing the mock-up may be used to concurrently:
column9: Specs state RSC for mock-up may be used to concurrently prequalify the RSC mix design.

column3: RSC used to construct abutments and bent caps must have minimum specified compressive strength of 4000 psi at:
column9: Specs add requirement for abutments and bent caps: 4000 psi minimum at age of break.

column3: Furnish a flow mold for testing UHPC under:
column9: Specs require furnishing a flow mold for testing UHPC under ASTM C1856.

column3: Provide cylinder molds for UHPC compressive strength testing that are:
column9: Specs require 3-inch diameter cylinder molds for UHPC compressive strength testing.

column3: Who performs flow testing and prepares UHPC cylinders for testing?
column9: Specs state UHPC manufacturers representative performs flow testing and prepares cylinders.

column3: Before starting mock-up work you must obtain authorization of QC plans for PC members and:
column9: Specs require authorization of QC plans for PC members and UHPC mock-up work plan before starting mock-up work.

column3: Notify the Engineer at least how many business days before starting assembly of UHPC mock-ups?
column9: Specs require notifying Engineer at least 3 business days before starting assembly of mock-ups.

column3: UHPC definition includes water-to-cementitious ratio less than 0.25 and high percentage of:
column9: Specs define UHPC as cementitious composite with w/cm less than 0.25 and high percentage of discontinuous internal fiber reinforcement.

column3: Department uses strength-maturity results from mock-up to determine compressive strength of UHPC placed in the field by using:
column9: Specs require using strength-maturity relationship verified during mock-up to determine field UHPC strength via maturity index.

column3: Why is RSC mock-up thermal control plan validation critical for bent caps and abutments?
column5: These elements are mass concrete and require temperature differential control
column9: Specs designate bent caps and abutments as mass concrete and require compliance with thermal control plan and maximum temperature differential requirements.
